awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: GI CATALYTIC TRACK: Cyberinfrastructure for Intelligent High-Resolution Snow Cover Inference from Cubesat Imagery
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to observe the Earth from space at relevant spatial and temporal scales is key to understanding how hydrological and ecological systems will respond to climate change. In particular, high spatial and temporal resolution (meter scale, daily frequency) observations of snow-covered areas in mountain regions are critical as snow is important for water resources, driving the seasonal hydrological regimes of the Western U.S., with significant impacts on ecological communities. Planet Labs, Inc. (Planet) is a promising new source of commercial Cubesat high-resolution imagery that can be used in environmental science, as it has both high spatial (3.0-4.0 m) and temporal (1-2 day) resolution. This project will develop open-source, cloud-based cyberinfrastructure including an automated pipeline for processing, analyzing and interpreting Planet Cubesat image data using a machine learning approach to infer snow cover at meter-scale resolution. All models and data products will be openly available for use and modification by scientific communities. The project will support the training of students, postdocs and other early-career researchers through training events, special interest groups, and incubator programs. 

Currently, remotely-sensed snow observations with adequate temporal (daily) resolution are either captured at a spatial scale far too large to be relevant to high-resolution hydrology and ecology studies (e.g. MODIS, 500m) or are appropriate in spatial scale (1-10 m) but have inadequate temporal resolution and are cost-prohibitive (e.g. airborne LiDAR). The recent increase of commercial Earth Observation data with high spatiotemporal resolution may bridge the gap between ground-based and low-resolution satellite observation data. This project will focus on using convolutional neural networks-based models to couple ground and airborne-derived snow observations with Planet imagery in three different montane systems in Washington, California, and Colorado. These sites have very good coverage of ground and airborne snow observations at high resolution (3m) collected by the NASA Airborne Snow Observatory (ASO) and SnowEx missions, which will be used in the training and validation of the models. The project will develop advanced cyberinfrastructure using scalable virtual machines, distributed collaborative architecture, reusable computational frameworks, and replicable machine learning workflows to empower Earth scientists to access, process and generate high-resolution snow products from Cubesat data. The project will adopt open-source strategies and ensure that all data, algorithms, and architecture comply with FAIR data principles and reproducibility and will include training materials that promote the adoption of the infrastructure and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mountain snowpack provides critical water for forest and meadow ecosystems experiencing rapid change due to global warming.  Accurate characterization of snow cover around trees and in forest gaps is essential for effective natural resource management in montane forest ecosystems and for advancing our understanding of the critical interactions between forests and snow processes. Snow cover mapping at meter-scale resolution is also important for monitoring meadow ecosystems. Snow impacts vegetation phenology (life stages for plant species such as flowering) and downstream hydrological systems. This project advanced snow hydrology research by pioneering the application of machine learning-based snow mapping workflows for snow identification in meter-scale spatial resolution optical imagery. By experimenting with different types of machine learning models, we've showcased the efficacy of both classical ML approaches (e.g., random forest) and deep learning for identifying snow at a 3-5 meter scale using Planetscope optical imagery from Planet. 

Within this project, we created open-source software and reproducible workflows for model reusability and broader application. We showed that machine learning models are effective when used with data from sensors with limited radiometric information, such as Planetscope imagery. Our first model used the Planetscope red, green, blue, and near-infrared information and a deep-learning segmentation model to derive snow cover maps. The model was trained using a dataset from California and then additionally tested in Colorado, a different geographic region. We then extended this model to include other features such as those derived from topographic information. Finally, we also trained a random forest model and evaluated the quality of the model-derived snow maps across various land cover types, including mountain meadows and forested areas. We found that the random forest model has a performance comparable to the more sophisticated deep-learning models while being easier to train and use. As a case study, we tested the model performance across 7,741 mountain meadows in the Sierra Nevada, California, and evaluated the model performance as a function of meadow size and shape complexity. 

Our workflows have been integrated within the advanced Geoweaver system, ensuring they are not only robust and reliable but also reusable, extendable, and adherent to FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) principles. These workflows are published as GitHub repositories under the MIT license and registered in Zenodo for citation, freely accessible for use and modification by the snow hydrology community. By harnessing Geoweaver's capabilities, our workflows are poised for broader adoption and application within the scientific community, facilitating collaborative research and accelerating advancements in snow hydrology.

In addition to technological advancements, our project has actively engaged with the scientific community through various community activities. We developed an educational Jupyter book, providing researchers and students with comprehensive resources for applying machine learning to geospatial data analysis. The content of the educational material has also been delivered in person at a hands-on training event organized at the University of Washington and online in 2023. Furthermore, we shared our experience using machine learning in an interview and blog post with  Earth Science Information Partners, ESIP,  a nonprofit organization that provides a neutral space for exciting cross-domain collaborations. These community-driven initiatives have not only facilitated knowledge exchange but have also catalyzed interdisciplinary collaboration, pushing the boundaries of snow hydrology research. 

The impact of our project extends beyond the scientific community, with broader social implications for water resource management, ecosystem conservation, and climate change adaptation. Accurate snow mapping is critical for assessing water availability, predicting flood risks, and monitoring ecosystem health, making our advancements in snow hydrology useful for informed decision-making and sustainable resource management. By promoting open science practices and advancing reproducible research methodologies, our project contributes to the larger goal of enhancing transparency, accountability, and trustworthiness in scientific research, ultimately fostering a culture of collaboration and innovation in the pursuit of addressing complex environmental challenges.
